Prompt: Provide an example of how a table of contents can be generated automatically in a LATEX document. Make sure your example contains the necessary commands.
Response: To create the table of contents is straightforward, the command \tableofcontents does the job. Sections, subsections and chapters are included in the table of contents. To manually add entries, for example when you want an unnumbered section, use the command \addcontentsline as shown in the following example:/n/n\documentclass{article}/n\usepackage{blindtext}/n\usepackage{titlesec}/n\title{Sections and Chapters}/n\author{Gubert Farnsworth}/n\date{ }/n\begin{document}/n\maketitle/n\tableofcontents/n\section{Introduction}/nThis is the first section./n\blindtext/n\addcontentsline{toc}{section}{Unnumbered Section}/n\section*{Unnumbered Section}/n\blindtext/n\section{Second Section}/n\blindtext/n\end{document}
Instruct&Context: Provide an example of how a table of contents can be generated automatically in a LATEX document.|||Make sure your example contains the necessary commands.

Prompt: You are given a description that provides a set of facts or a scenario. It is up to you to craft a story from these facts and scenarios. The missing pieces must be filled in with imaginative but logical information./n/nInput: Ten European football teams – the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Wales – will participate in a season-long “OneLove” campaign promoting inclusion and opposing discrimination./n/nOutput:
Response: Every country except Sweden and Norway has qualified for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar and each captain of these eight nations will wear a distinctive OneLove armband – which features a heart containing colors from all backgrounds – during the tournament./nThe Netherlands FA, which is spearheading the campaign, chose the colors to represent all heritages, backgrounds, genders and sexual identities; the armband will be worn in Qatar where same-sex relationships are a criminal offense./nSweden and Norway will participate in the initiative during the upcoming Nations League matches, while England will also wear black armbands during both its UEFA Nations League matches to mark the death of Queen Elizabeth II./n“This is an important message which suits the game of football: on the field everybody is equal and this should be the case in every place in society. With the OneLove band we express this message,” said Virgil van Dijk, the Netherlands captain./n“On behalf of the Dutch team I have been wearing this band for quite a while now. It is good to see that other countries are joining this initiative.”/nOneLove was founded in the Netherlands in 2020 to emphasize that all football fans have at least one thing in common – their love of football – and to speak out against any form of discrimination./nAs well as focusing on public messaging, the initiative has also developed to offer diversity training to grassroots club./n“Our love of football unites us all. No matter where you come from, what you look like and who you love. Football is there for everyone and our sport must stand up for the people across the world who face discrimination and exclusion,” said Germany captain Manuel Neuer./n“I am proud to be sending out this message with my colleagues from the other national teams. Every single voice counts.”/nIn June, England’s captain Harry Kane revealed that he had discussed taking a collective stance regarding human rights in Qatar with Denmark’s Christian Eriksen and France captain Hugo Lloris./n“I am honored to join my fellow national team captains in supporting the important OneLove campaign,” he said on Tuesday./n“As captains we may all be competing against each other on the pitch, but we stand together against all forms of discrimination. This is even more relevant at a time when division is common in society. Wearing the armband together on behalf of our teams will send a clear message when the world is watching.”
Instruct&Context: You are given a description that provides a set of facts or a scenario. It is up to you to craft a story from these facts and scenarios. The missing pieces must be filled in with imaginative but logical information.|||Input: &&&Ten European football teams – the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Wales – will participate in a season-long “OneLove” campaign promoting inclusion and opposing discrimination.

Response: 1- Under your repository name, click Pull requests./n2- In the "Pull Requests" list, click the pull request with a merge conflict that you'd like to resolve./n3- Near the bottom of your pull request, click Resolve conflicts./n4- Decide if you want to keep only your branch's changes, keep only the other branch's changes, or make a brand new change, which may incorporate changes from both branches. Delete the conflict markers <<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>> and make the changes you want in the final merge./n5- If you have more than one merge conflict in your file, scroll down to the next set of conflict markers and repeat steps four and five to resolve your merge conflict./n6- Once you've resolved all the conflicts in the file, click Mark as resolved./n7- If you have more than one file with a conflict, select the next file you want to edit on the left side of the page under "conflicting files" and repeat steps four through seven until you've resolved all of your pull request's merge conflicts./n8- Once you've resolved all your merge conflicts, click Commit merge. This merges the entire base branch into your head branch./n9- If prompted, review the branch that you are committing to./nIf the head branch is the default branch of the repository, you can choose either to update this branch with the changes you made to resolve the conflict, or to create a new branch and use this as the head branch of the pull request./nIf you choose to create a new branch, enter a name for the branch./nIf the head branch of your pull request is protected you must create a new branch. You won't get the option to update the protected branch./nClick Create branch and update my pull request or I understand, continue updating BRANCH. The button text corresponds to the action you are performing./n10- To merge your pull request, click Merge pull request. For more information about other pull request merge options, see "Merging a pull request."
Instruct&Context: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.

Prompt: Give a brief summary of the movie or series' plot./n/nInput: Breaking Bad (TV Series 2008–2013)/n/nOutput:
Response: Walter H. White is a chemistry genius, but works as a chemistry teacher in an Albequerque, New Mexico high school. His life drastically changes when he's diagnosed with stage III terminal lung cancer, and given a short amount of time left to live: a mere matter of months. To ensure his handicapped son and his pregnant wife have a financial future, Walt uses his chemistry background to create and sell the world's finest crystal methamphetamine. To sell his signature "blue meth," he teams up with Jesse Pinkman, a former student of his. The meth makes them very rich very quickly, but it attracts the attention of his DEA brother in law Hank. As Walt and Jesse's status in the drug world escalates, Walt becomes a dangerous criminal and Jesse becomes a hot-headed salesman. Hank is always hot on his tail, and it forces Walt to come up with new ways to cover his tracks.
Instruct&Context: Give a brief summary of the movie or series' plot|||Input: Breaking Bad (TV Series 2008–2013)

Prompt: Answer the following question./n/nInput: How do I compare strings in Java?/nI've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into.equals() instead, and it fixed the bug./nIs == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference?/n/nOutput:
Response: == tests for reference equality (whether they are the same object)./n.equals() tests for value equality (whether they are logically "equal")./nObjects.equals() checks for null before calling .equals() so you don't have to (available as of JDK7, also available in Guava)./nConsequently, if you want to test whether two strings have the same value you will probably want to use Objects.equals()./nYou almost always want to use Objects.equals(). In the rare situation where you know you're dealing with interned strings, you can use ==.
Instruct&Context: Answer the following question.|||compare strings in Java|||When should it and should it not be used?|||What's the difference?

Prompt: Provide a Java solution to the following problem./n/nInput: Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false./nAn integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x./n/nExample 1:/nIn: n = 27/nOut: true/nExplanation: 27 = 3^3/n/nExample 2:/nIn: n = 0/nOut: false/nExplanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0./n/nExample 3:/nIn: n = -1/nOut: false/nExplanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1)./n /nConstraints:/n-231 <= n <= 231 - 1/nFollow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?/n/nOutput:
Response: public class Solution {/n    public boolean isPowerOfThree(int n) {/n        return (Math.log10(n) / Math.log10(3)) % 1 == 0;/n    }/n}
Instruct&Context: Provide a Java solution

Prompt: The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary./n/nInput: Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine./n/nOutput:
Response: Although zinc is an essential requirement for good health, excess zinc can be harmful. Excessive absorption of zinc suppresses copper and iron absorption. The free zinc ion in solution is highly toxic to plants, invertebrates, and even vertebrate fish. The Free Ion Activity Model is well-established in the literature, and shows that just micromolar amounts of the free ion kills some organisms. A recent example showed 6 micromolar killing 93% of all Daphnia in water./nThe free zinc ion is a powerful Lewis acid up to the point of being corrosive. Stomach acid contains hydrochloric acid, in which metallic zinc dissolves readily to give corrosive zinc chloride. Swallowing a post-1982 American one cent piece (97.5% zinc) can cause damage to the stomach lining through the high solubility of the zinc ion in the acidic stomach.
Instruct&Context: The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.

Prompt: Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner./n/nInput: Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts./nMathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting./n/nOutput:
Response: This article discusses the relationship between mathematics and art, with a focus on visual arts. It describes how artists have used mathematics since ancient times, and how mathematics has inspired various textile arts.
Instruct&Context: Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.|||Input: &&&Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. Response: The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right./nImporting firms voluntarily adhere to fair trade standards or governments may enforce them through a combination of employment and commercial law. Non-governmental organizations also play a role in promoting fair trade standards by serving as independent monitors of compliance with labeling requirements. As such, it is a form of Protectionism.

Prompt: Make the article available in a second language by translating it into it./n/nInput: Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist./nTranslate to French:/n/nOutput:
Response: La dentisterie, également connue sous le nom de médecine dentaire et de médecine buccale, est la branche de la médecine axée sur les dents, les gencives et la bouche. Il consiste en l'étude, le diagnostic, la prévention, la gestion et le traitement des maladies, troubles et affections de la bouche, le plus souvent axés sur la dentition (le développement et la disposition des dents) ainsi que sur la muqueuse buccale./nLa dentisterie peut également englober d'autres aspects du complexe craniofacial, y compris l'articulation temporo-mandibulaire. Le praticien est appelé dentiste.
Instruct&Context: Make the article available in a second language by translating it into it.|||Input: |||Translate to French:&&&Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.

Prompt: Design a syllabus for the given course. Students should be given a list of the chapters with brief explanations of each chapter's purpose./n/nInput: Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)/n/nOutput:
Response: - Chapter One - Why we Program?/nThese are the course-wide materials as well as the first part of Chapter One where we explore what it means to write programs. We finish Chapter One and have the quiz and first assignment in the third week of the class. Throughout the course you may want to come back and look at these materials. This section should not take you an entire week./n- Installing and Using Python/nIn this module you will set things up so you can write Python programs. Not all activities in this module are required for this class so please read the "Using Python in this Class" material for details./n- Chapter One: Why We Program (continued)/nIn the first chapter we try to cover the "big picture" of programming so you get a "table of contents" of the rest of the book. Don't worry if not everything makes perfect sense the first time you hear it. This chapter is quite broad and you would benefit from reading the chapter in the book in addition to watching the lectures to help it all sink in. You might want to come back and re-watch these lectures after you have funished a few more chapters./n- Chapter Two: Variables and Expressions/nIn this chapter we cover how a program uses the computer's memory to store, retrieve and calculate information./n- Chapter Three: Conditional Code/nIn this section we move from sequential code that simply runs one line of code after another to conditional code where some steps are skipped. It is a very simple concept - but it is how computer software makes "choices"./n- Chapter Four: Functions/nThis is a relatively short chapter. We will learn about what functions are and how we can use them. The programs in the first chapters of the book are not large enough to require us to develop functions, but as the book moves into more and more complex programs, functions will be an essential way for us to make sense of our code./n- Chapter Five: Loops and Iteration/nLoops and iteration complete our four basic programming patterns. Loops are the way we tell Python to do something over and over. Loops are the way we build programs that stay with a problem until the problem is solved.
Instruct&Context: Design a syllabus for the given course. Students should be given a list of the chapters with brief explanations of each chapter's purpose.|||Input: Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)

Prompt: Create a daily itinerary based on the given information./n/nInput: Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels./n/nOutput:
Response: 1- DAY 1: MARRAKECH/nArrive in time to meet your fellow travelers for a welcome gathering this evening. Your arrival transfer is included./n2- DAY 2: MARRAKECH/OUARZAZATE/nWind past red slopes and green terraces as we make our way south through the stunning valleys of Morocco’s High Atlas Mountains, stopping to enjoy a picnic lunch beside a sparkling river. Arrive in Ouarzazate, known as the “gateway to the Sahara,” and step behind the scenes at a film studio to see how the surrounding dunes have starred on the silver screen./n3- DAY 3: OUARZAZATE/MERZOUGA/nToday, travel between jagged peaks and palm oases toward the desert town of Merzouga. Settle into our hotel near the incredible Erg Chebbi, a sweeping sea of dunes formed by wind-blown sand. As the sun sets, savour a traditional Amazigh dinner, then spread a blanket on the sand for an evening of desert stargazing./n4- DAY 4: MERZOUGA/nThis morning, hop aboard a 4x4 and ride across the dunes to discover fossils left behind by an ancient sea, and be entranced by Gnaoua musicians in a local village. Return to the hotel for free time to cool off in the pool. Enjoy a tasty Amazigh dinner, then gather around a glowing bonfire for a storytelling session./n5- DAY 5: MERZOUGA/DADES GORGE/nVenture into the rugged landscape of the Dades Gorge, a dramatic and colourful valley carved by the waters of the Dades River. Visit a local village for lunch and enjoy a special dish—traditional Amazigh pizza! Wind through the valley on a guided walk as you learn about the amazing geology behind the weird and wonderful rock formations of the Gorge. This evening, enjoy free time to relax at the hotel./n6- DAY 6: DADES GORGE/AÏT BEN HADDOU/nDrive through the Ounila Valley to the ancient fortified village of Aït Ben Haddou, a UNESCO World Heritage site where clay houses crowd together in a traditional ksar behind defensive walls. Explore alleyways twisting between historic structures, and stand guard atop the clay brick ramparts, taking in views of the green oasis around this imposing fort. Entertain your taste buds at a hands-on tagine cooking class, followed by a delicious dinner./n7- DAY 7: AÏT BEN HADDOU/MARRAKECH/nJourney through the mountains to Marrakech, known as the “red city” for its walls, houses, and many mosques built from red clay. After checking into your hotel and resting up, head to a local henna workshop to have your hands painted in this ancient temporary tattooing art. Then, explore the lively Djemaa el Fna, an ancient marketplace still used as the main square in Marrakech. After, enjoy free time to discover more of Marrakech./n8- DAY 8: MARRAKECH /nWake up as the call to prayer echoes across the city. After breakfast, set out on a guided walk through the narrow, maze-like streets of the medina, lined with colorful shops brimming with rugs, spices, and much more. Spend the rest of the day exploring Marrakech on your own, or opt to explore the Marjorelle Garden. In the evening, gather for a farewell dinner in a traditional riad, a grand house with an elegant interior courtyard./n9- DAY 9: MARRAKECH/nDepart at any time.
Instruct&Context: Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.|||Input: Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels.

Prompt: Think of an idea to help you win a challenge given to you. Write the steps you need to take to develop the idea as well./n/nInput: What can you make by recycling and repurposing some old, previously used materials? We want to see it!/nProjects must incorporate some kind of used materials - take that old used thing, and turn it into something new and different!/nE-waste is a huge problem. What can you make using old electronics and other salvageable electronic materials? /nWe have a special judges prize for our favorite Instructable that incorporates or is related to reusing e-waste./nBe smart and be safe; note that potentially deadly projects (like Lichtenberg/fractal wood burning machines) will not be allowed to be published or submitted to this contest./n/nOutput:
Response: This power booster recycles a 'dead' battery to power a 1.8 volt red LED light. It's mainly made from recycled parts./nWhen a 1.5 volt battery is new it will probably have more than 1.5 volts in it. As the battery is used the voltage will decrease until the voltage is not enough to run the application ( E.g. a red LED) and will be called 'dead' . But a Dead battery still has some power remaining in it - just not enough voltage. The trick is to use some of that remaining power to increase the voltage in a circuit. The trade off being there will be a reduction in current./nHere is the required steps:/n1- Connect a switch to a battery holder. A soldiering iron and hot glue gun assisted with this./n2- Make a small pyramid above the battery holder using 4 bamboo skewer sticks secured with hot glue./n3- Soldier on a 1.8 volt red LED at the top of the mini Christmas tree./n4- Test the LED glows with a new battery (1.6 volts)/n5- Test the LED doesn't glow with a dead battery (1.2 volts)/n6- Add in the buzzer circuit, along with a switch./n7- Add in the windings circuit - to touch the striker of the buzzer a little copper foil was added./n8- Insert a dead battery (1.2 volt) with the buzzer circuit turned switch off - the LED will not glow but when the buzzer circuit is switched on the Red LED lights up.
Instruct&Context: Think of an idea to help you win a challenge given to you. Write the steps you need to take to develop the idea as well.|||Input: What can you make by recycling and repurposing some old, previously used materials?&&&We want to see it!/nProjects must incorporate some kind of used materials - take that old used thing, and turn it into something new and different!/nE-waste is a huge problem. Prompt: Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project./n/nInput: Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can/n/nOutput:
Response: Step 1: Close Drink Opening/nTo build up steam the beverage can needs to act as a pressure vessel and so needs to be completely sealed, except where the steam will come out of the jet nozzles. It also needs to rotate on itself. Bend up the outer tab into a L shape using some pilers and then bend it forward so a piece of string can hang from it over the center of the can. This will allow the can to rotate on itself. Close the pouring opening by using a knife or other thin object, bending the opening back up so it almost where it was before the beverage can was opened./nStep 2: Nozzel Jets/nMake a couple of holes in the side of the can, about half way up, opposite each other using a small drill. The diameter of the holes should be about the same as the thin plastic tubing to be used as jet nozzles. Enlarge the holes so they are elliptical allowing the nozzle tubes to lie parallel against the cans side./nStep 3: Making a Pressure Vessel/nSeal the top of the opened can using super glue and baking soda to make a small pressure vessel. Add some super glue to the closed opening and then sprinkle on some baking soda - they will combine to make a plastic. Keep adding super glue and baking soda until the top is sealed./nStep 4: Attaching the Nozzle Jets/nFit in the thin plastic tubes to the holes drilled in the sides of the can and seal with super glue and baking soda. Try to have the tubes pointing horizontal in the direction you want to rotate the can when the steam exits the nozzles./nStep 5: Creating Steam/nAdd a little water into the can though one of the nozzles. Just add maybe a teaspoon or so. /nStep 6: In Action/nThe can was suspended from a tripod over the methylated sprits flame. After a couple of minutes enough steam had built up to rotate the can.
Instruct&Context: Provide a detailed explanation of the steps|||construct the given project|||Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can

Prompt: Answer the following literature question as accurately as possible based on your knowledge of literature for high school students./n/nInput: What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?/n/nOutput:
Response: The green light symbolizes several different things to different characters throughout the book, but overall, it stands for the inaccessibility of the American Dream. At the start of the novel, the light symbolizes Gatsby's unwavering love for Daisy. He stands at the end of the dock gazing across the bay, reaching for the light, waiting for Daisy to come back to him. His hope, like the eternal green light, is unfaltering. It isn't until Daisy admits later that she had never really noticed the light that the facade began to slip. Nick, the narrator, starts to recognize it as a symbol of Gatsby's unhealthy desperation rather than his love. This is parallel to Gatsby's experience of the American Dream and money. Gatsby is unbelievably rich at the beginning of the novel. This solidifies his belief in the American Dream, though he still reaches for the acceptance of those who are wealthier and more popular. Nick believes money is not an object to Gatsby, though he has no idea how he made all of it. As the story unfolds and the mystery and mystique around Gatsby fade, so does Gatsby and Nick's blind belief and trust in the American Dream. After Gatsby is murdered, the green light is symbolic of the ways that money and affluence ruin the lives of those without. It is also symbolic of the way that the American dream ruins the lives of those eternally reaching for it.
Instruct&Context: What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?

Prompt: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
Response: Submodalities/nGiving a physical form to your anxiety can help your mind feel more in control of it. In this exercise, we will visualize what anxiety looks and feels like, and learn to reduce its intensity. Here are the questions that you need to answer:/n1- Everyone feels anxiety differently. Where in your body do you feel it?/n2- Now close your eyes and picture your anxiety. Try to give it color, shape, and temperature. What does it feel like?/n3- Does it move, or is it in one place? If it moves, tell how it is moving./n4- Now for the good part, close your eyes and try changing this picture. Change how it moves. Slow it done shrink its size. Try to move it away from your body. Imagine it fading. Keep doing this until you feel like you can change how it feels. Changing which submodality helped you curb your anxiety? Was it its shape, size, or something else?/n5- Do you feel better now?
Instruct&Context: Develop a mental exercise|||help people manage their anxiety|||explain how it works

Prompt: Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them./n/nInput: Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies/n/nOutput:
Response: Ingredients (for 12 cookies):/n½ cup granulated sugar(100 g)/n¾ cup brown sugar(165 g), packed/n1 teaspoon salt/n½ cup unsalted butter(115 g), melted/n1 egg/n1 teaspoon vanilla extract/n1 ¼ cups all-purpose flour(155 g)/n½ teaspoon baking soda/n4 oz milk or semi-sweet chocolate chunks(110 g)/n4 oz dark chocolate chunk(110 g), or your preference/nPreparation:/nIn a large bowl, whisk together the sugars, salt, and butter until a paste forms with no lumps./nWhisk in the egg and vanilla, beating until light ribbons fall off the whisk and remain for a short while before falling back into the mixture./nSift in the flour and baking soda, then fold the mixture with a spatula (Be careful not to overmix, which would cause the gluten in the flour to toughen resulting in cakier cookies)./nFold in the chocolate chunks, then chill the dough for at least 30 minutes. For a more intense toffee-like flavor and deeper color, chill the dough overnight. The longer the dough rests, the more complex its flavor will be./nPreheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper./nScoop the dough with an ice-cream scoop onto a parchment paper-lined baking sheet, leaving at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space between cookies and 2 inches (5 cm) of space from the edges of the pan so that the cookies can spread evenly./nBake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges have started to barely brown./nCool completely before serving.
Instruct&Context: Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words.|||Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.|||Input: Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies

Prompt: Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper./n/nInput: Paper: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data./nExplain: The dominant sequence transduction models/n/nOutput:
Response: The dominant sequence transduction models are the most common models used to translate between two languages. These models are based on complex neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism.
Instruct&Context: Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper.|||Explain: The dominant sequence transduction models&&&The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.

We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Prompt: Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract./n/nInput: Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance./n/nOutput:
Response: This paper introduces FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding, and guides slot with explicit intent information and proposes a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing.
Instruct&Context: Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.|||Input: &&&Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.

Prompt: I'm writing a NeurIPS paper about a new model architecture for processing and generating long texts. Here are some facts about the paper:/n* The main trick is to replace some of the attention heads with an exponential moving average, where the decay rate is learned for each head. We call this architecture ExeMA./n* On language modeling, the perplexity difference between our model and a vanilla transformer is negligible, but that's because next-token prediction is almost always a local task, so perplexity won't be sensitive enough to detect any improvements in long-range understanding./n* However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the baseline./n* We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline./nHelp me write the paper's introduction.
Response: Title: ExeMA: A Novel Model Architecture for Processing and Generating Long Texts with Improved Coherence/n/n1. Introduction/n/nThe ability to process and generate long texts is a crucial aspect of natural language understanding and generation. Traditional models, such as the Transformer, have shown remarkable performance in various natural language processing tasks. However, their ability to capture long-range dependencies and maintain coherence in generated text remains a challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel model architecture, Exponential Moving Average for Transformers (ExeMA), which addresses these limitations and demonstrates improved performance in processing and generating long texts./n/nThe main innovation in ExeMA is the replacement of some attention heads with an exponential moving average (EMA), where the decay rate is learned for each head. This modification allows the model to better capture long-range dependencies and maintain coherence in generated text, without sacrificing the performance on local tasks such as next-token prediction./n/nWe evaluate our proposed architecture on language modeling tasks and find that the perplexity difference between ExeMA and a vanilla Transformer is negligible. This is expected, as next-token prediction is predominantly a local task, and perplexity is not sensitive enough to detect improvements in long-range understanding. However, when evaluated on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model demonstrates a significant improvement of 10% over the baseline, indicating its enhanced ability to process and generate long texts./n/nTo further validate the effectiveness of ExeMA in generating coherent text, we introduce a new metric, Coherence in Generated Text (CoGnaTe). Our experiments show that the text generated by our model is 43% more coherent than the baseline, highlighting the benefits of incorporating EMA in the Transformer architecture./n/nIn summary, this paper makes the following contributions:/n/n1. We propose ExeMA, a novel model architecture that replaces some attention heads with an exponential moving average, enabling improved processing and generation of long texts./n2. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ExeMA on the SCROLLS benchmark, where our model outperforms the baseline by 10%./n3. We introduce CoGnaTe, a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text, and show that ExeMA generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline./n/nThe remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 provides a background on the Transformer architecture and the motivation for ExeMA. Section 3 describes the proposed ExeMA architecture in detail. Section 4 presents the experimental setup and results, including the evaluation on the SCROLLS benchmark and the CoGnaTe metric. Finally, Section 5 concludes the paper and discusses future research directions.

We call this architecture ExeMA./n* On language modeling, the perplexity difference between our model and a vanilla transformer is negligible, but that's because next-token prediction is almost always a local task, so perplexity won't be sensitive enough to detect any improvements in long-range understanding./n* However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the baseline./n* We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline./nHelp me write the paper's introduction.

Prompt: I have an exercise in game of theory class that I should find all equilibriums in rock paper scissors game. Could you help me with this exercise?
Response: In the Rock-Paper-Scissors game, there are three strategies: Rock (R), Paper (P), and Scissors (S). The game is symmetric, meaning that each player has the same set of strategies and payoffs. The game is typically played as a one-shot game, meaning that players choose their strategies simultaneously and without prior knowledge of their opponent's choice./n/nTo find the Nash equilibria in this game, we need to identify the situations in which no player has an incentive to unilaterally change their strategy, given the strategy of the other player./n/nIn a pure strategy Nash equilibrium, each player chooses one strategy with certainty. However, in Rock-Paper-Scissors, there is no pure strategy Nash equilibrium. To see why, consider any pair of pure strategies, such as both players choosing Rock. In this case, one player could switch to Paper and win, so neither player is playing a best response to the other's strategy./n/nInstead, we need to look for a mixed strategy Nash equilibrium, where each player chooses their strategy with a certain probability. In this case, the mixed strategy Nash equilibrium occurs when each player chooses each of the three strategies with equal probability (1/3 for Rock, 1/3 for Paper, and 1/3 for Scissors)./n/nTo verify that this is a Nash equilibrium, we need to show that no player has an incentive to deviate from this strategy, given that the other player is also using it. Suppose player 1 chooses Rock with probability p_R, Paper with probability p_P, and Scissors with probability p_S. Similarly, let player 2 choose Rock with probability q_R, Paper with probability q_P, and Scissors with probability q_S./n/nPlayer 1's expected payoff from choosing Rock is:/n/nE(R) = p_R * (0 * q_R + 1 * q_S + (-1) * q_P) = p_R * (q_S - q_P)/n/nSimilarly, the expected payoffs from choosing Paper and Scissors are:/n/nE(P) = p_P * (1 * q_R + 0 * q_S + (-1) * q_P) = p_P * (q_R - q_S)/nE(S) = p_S * (1 * q_P + (-1) * q_R + 0 * q_S) = p_S * (q_P - q_R)/n/nIn equilibrium, these expected payoffs must be equal:/n/nE(R) = E(P) = E(S)/n/nSubstituting the equilibrium probabilities, we get:/n/n(1/3) * (q_S - q_P) = (1/3) * (q_R - q_S) = (1/3) * (q_P - q_R)/n/nSince the probabilities must sum to 1, we have:/n/nq_R + q_P + q_S = 1/n/nSolving these equations, we find that the unique mixed strategy Nash equilibrium is:/n/nq_R = q_P = q_S = 1/3/n/nSo, the only Nash equilibrium in the Rock-Paper-Scissors game is when both players choose each strategy with equal probability (1/3 for Rock, 1/3 for Paper, and 1/3 for Scissors).
Instruct&Context: I have an exercise in game of theory class that I should find all equilibriums in rock paper scissors game.|||Could you help me with this exercise?

Prompt: Who are some eminent scholars of the Quechua language?
Response: 1. Bernardino de Sahagún (1499-1590): A Franciscan friar, missionary, and linguist who studied and documented the Quechua language during the early colonial period in Peru./n/n2. Juan de Betanzos (1510-1576): A Spanish conquistador and chronicler who learned Quechua and wrote one of the earliest grammars of the language./n/n3. Diego González Holguín (1552-1620): A Jesuit priest and linguist who wrote an important Quechua-Spanish dictionary and grammar./n/n4. Ludovico Bertonio (1552-1625): An Italian Jesuit missionary who worked in the Andean region and wrote several works on the Quechua language, including a dictionary and grammar./n/n5. César Itier (born 1957): A French linguist and professor at the Institut National des Langues et Civilisations Orientales (INALCO) in Paris, who specializes in the study of the Quechua language and Andean cultures./n/n6. Rodolfo Cerrón-Palomino (born 1940): A Peruvian linguist and professor at the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru, who has published extensively on the Quechua language and its dialects./n/n7. Gary Parker (born 1939): An American linguist and professor emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley, who has conducted extensive research on the Quechua language and its dialects./n/n8. Willem Adelaar (born 1948): A Dutch linguist and professor at Leiden University, who has published extensively on the Quechua language and its dialects, as well as other indigenous languages of South America./n/n9. Sabine Dedenbach-Salazar Sáenz (born 1958): A German anthropologist and linguist who specializes in the study of the Quechua language and Andean cultures, and has published several works on the subject./n/n10. Bruce Mannheim (born 1952): An American anthropologist and linguist who has conducted extensive research on the Quechua language and its dialects, as well as the cultural practices of the Quechua-speaking peoples.
Instruct&Context: Who are some eminent scholars of the Quechua language?

Prompt: How do I find out which process is using my webcam on macOS?
Response: To find out which process is using your webcam on macOS, follow these steps:/n/n1. Open Terminal: You can find Terminal in the Utilities folder within the Applications folder, or you can use Spotlight search by pressing `Cmd + Space` and typing "Terminal."/n/n2. In the Terminal window, enter the following command:/n/n```/nlsof | grep "AppleCamera"/n```/n/n3. Press `Enter` to execute the command. This command will list all processes that are currently using the AppleCamera (webcam)./n/n4. If a process is using your webcam, you will see output similar to this:/n/n```/nProcessName  PID  User  FD  TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME/n```/n/nHere, `ProcessName` is the name of the process using the webcam, and `PID` is the process ID./n/n5. If you want to close the process using the webcam, you can use the `kill` command followed by the process ID:/n/n```/nkill PID/n```/n/nReplace `PID` with the actual process ID from the previous step./n/n6. Press `Enter` to execute the command and close the process using the webcam./n/nPlease note that closing a process may cause data loss or other issues, so make sure you save your work before killing a process.
Instruct&Context: How do I find out which process is using my webcam on macOS?

Spend some time relaxing at your hotel's spa or pool before checking out./n- Do some last-minute shopping or sightseeing before heading to the airport for your departure.

Prompt: Write an opinion piece about why diversity and inclusion is super important for the tech industry. The essay should be targeted at "tech bros", and should avoid alienating them, but instead appeal to their logic; it should explain how diversity and inclusion of women, immigrants, etc. could benefit them specifically.
Response: Title: The Tech Industry Needs Diversity and Inclusion: Here's Why It Matters to You/n/nDear Tech Bros,/n/nLet's talk about diversity and inclusion in the tech industry. Before you roll your eyes and dismiss this as another "politically correct" rant, hear me out. This isn't about being politically correct or checking off boxes. This is about the future of the tech industry and how embracing diversity and inclusion can benefit you and your career./n/nFirst, let's address the elephant in the room: the tech industry has a diversity problem. According to a 2020 report by Statista, only 26.7% of the tech workforce in the United States are women, and the numbers for racial and ethnic minorities are similarly low. This lack of diversity isn't just a social issue; it's a business issue. Here's why:/n/n1. Diverse teams are more innovative and creative./n/nWhen you're working on a project, you want the best ideas, right? Well, diverse teams are more likely to come up with those ideas. A study by the Harvard Business Review found that diverse teams are more likely to have a broader range of perspectives, which leads to more innovative and creative solutions. So, if you want to be part of a team that's pushing the boundaries of what's possible, you should be advocating for diversity and inclusion./n/n2. Diverse companies are more profitable./n/nIt's not just about creativity and innovation; diverse companies are also more profitable. A study by McKinsey & Company found that companies in the top quartile for gender diversity on their executive teams were 21% more likely to have above-average profitability than those in the bottom quartile. The same study found that companies in the top quartile for ethnic and cultural diversity were 33% more likely to outperform their peers on profitability. So, if you want to work for a successful company (and who doesn't?), diversity and inclusion should be a priority./n/n3. Diversity helps companies avoid costly mistakes./n/nRemember that time when a certain tech giant released a facial recognition software that struggled to identify people with darker skin tones? That's the kind of mistake that can be avoided with a more diverse team. When you have people from different backgrounds working on a project, they're more likely to spot potential issues that might not be obvious to someone with a more homogenous perspective. In other words, diverse teams can help companies avoid costly and embarrassing mistakes./n/n4. Diversity and inclusion can help you attract top talent./n/nThe tech industry is incredibly competitive, and attracting top talent is crucial for success. A diverse and inclusive company culture can be a major selling point for potential employees. According to a Glassdoor survey, 67% of job seekers consider workplace diversity an important factor when evaluating job offers. So, if you want to work with the best and brightest, it's in your best interest to promote diversity and inclusion./n/n5. It's the right thing to do./n/nFinally, let's not forget that promoting diversity and inclusion is simply the right thing to do. The tech industry has the power to shape the future, and it's crucial that everyone has a seat at the table. By advocating for diversity and inclusion, you're helping to create a more equitable and just society./n/nSo, dear tech bros, it's time to embrace diversity and inclusion. It's not just about being "woke" or politically correct; it's about ensuring the continued success and innovation of the tech industry. And that's something we can all get behind.
Instruct&Context: Write an opinion piece about why diversity and inclusion is super important for the tech industry.|||The essay should be targeted at "tech bros", and should avoid alienating them, but instead appeal to their logic; it should explain how diversity and inclusion of women, immigrants, etc. could benefit them specifically.

Prompt: What is the most efficient way to get the number of rows in a table with psycog2?
Response: The most efficient way to get the number of rows in a table using psycopg2 is to execute a SQL query that counts the rows and fetches the result. Here's an example:/n/n```python/nimport psycopg2/n/n# Connect to the database/nconn = psycopg2.connect(database="your_database", user="your_user", password="your_password", host="your_host", port="your_port")/ncursor = conn.cursor()/n/n# Replace 'your_table' with the name of your table/ncursor.execute("SELECT COUNT(*) FROM your_table")/nrow_count = cursor.fetchone()[0]/n/nprint(f"Number of rows in the table: {row_count}")/n/n# Close the cursor and connection/ncursor.close()/nconn.close()/n```/n/nThis code connects to the database, executes a `SELECT COUNT(*)` query on the specified table, fetches the result, and prints the number of rows. Remember to replace the placeholders with your actual database credentials and table name.
Instruct&Context: What is the most efficient way to get the number of rows in a table with psycog2?

Prompt: What is the difference between the potato masala for Dosa and the one that is served with poori?
Response: The main difference between the potato masala for Dosa and the one served with Poori lies in the ingredients and the preparation method./n/nPotato Masala for Dosa:/n1. This potato masala is also known as "Dosa Aloo" or "Aloo Bhaji."/n2. It is usually made with boiled and mashed potatoes, onions, green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, mustard seeds, and urad dal./n3. The spices used in this masala are turmeric, asafoetida (hing), and sometimes red chili powder./n4. The consistency of this masala is slightly moist and semi-solid, making it easy to spread on the dosa./n5. It is usually less spicy compared to the potato masala served with poori./n/nPotato Masala for Poori:/n1. This potato masala is also known as "Poori Bhaji" or "Poori Aloo."/n2. It is made with boiled and cubed potatoes, onions, tomatoes, green chilies, ginger, and sometimes garlic./n3. The spices used in this masala are turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and sometimes amchur (dry mango powder) or lemon juice for tanginess./n4. The consistency of this masala is slightly more liquid, with a gravy-like texture, making it suitable for dipping the poori./n5. It is usually spicier compared to the potato masala used in dosa./n/nIn summary, the potato masala for dosa is milder in taste, has a semi-solid consistency, and uses fewer spices, while the potato masala for poori is spicier, has a gravy-like consistency, and uses a wider variety of spices.
Instruct&Context: What is the difference between the potato masala for Dosa and the one that is served with poori?

Prompt: what does \multirow{5}{*} do in latex
Response: In LaTeX, the command `\multirow{5}{*}` is used in a table environment to merge cells vertically. It takes two arguments:/n/n1. The first argument `5` specifies the number of rows to be merged./n2. The second argument `*` indicates that the width of the merged cell should be determined automatically based on the content./n/nHere's an example of how to use `\multirow`:/n/n```latex/n\documentclass{article}/n\usepackage{multirow}/n/n\begin{document}/n/n\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}/n\hline/n\multirow{5}{*}{Merged cell} & Column 2 & Column 3 \\/n\cline{2-3}/n                             & Column 2 & Column 3 \\/n\cline{2-3}/n                             & Column 2 & Column 3 \\/n\cline{2-3}/n                             & Column 2 & Column 3 \\/n\cline{2-3}/n                             & Column 2 & Column 3 \\/n\hline/n\end{tabular}/n/n\end{document}/n```/n/nThis code will create a table with three columns and five rows, where the first cell in the first column is merged vertically across all five rows.
Instruct&Context: what does \multirow{5}{*} do in latex

Prompt: Plan a day trip in Tokyo. The spots need to be within walking distance to each other.
Response: Start your day trip in Tokyo by visiting the famous Asakusa district. Here's a suggested itinerary with spots within walking distance to each other:/n/n1. Senso-ji Temple: Begin your day at Senso-ji, Tokyo's oldest and most famous Buddhist temple. Explore the temple grounds, take pictures of the iconic Kaminarimon Gate, and shop for souvenirs along Nakamise Street./n/n2. Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Center: Head to the Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Center to get a bird's-eye view of the Asakusa district from its observation deck. You can also find helpful information about the area and its attractions./n/n3. Sumida Park: Take a leisurely stroll along the Sumida River at Sumida Park, which is just a 10-minute walk from Senso-ji Temple. Enjoy the scenic views of the Tokyo Skytree and the river./n/n4. Tokyo Skytree: Walk for about 20 minutes from Sumida Park to reach Tokyo Skytree, the tallest tower in Japan. Go up to the observation deck for a panoramic view of Tokyo, or explore the shopping and dining options at the base of the tower./n/n5. Kappabashi Street: After visiting Tokyo Skytree, walk for about 15 minutes to Kappabashi Street, a famous shopping street for kitchenware and restaurant supplies. Browse through the unique shops selling everything from knives to plastic food samples./n/n6. Ueno Park: End your day trip with a visit to Ueno Park, which is about a 20-minute walk from Kappabashi Street. Explore the park's various attractions, such as the Tokyo National Museum, Ueno Zoo, and the beautiful Shinobazu Pond./n/nThroughout the day, you can also enjoy various food options in Asakusa, such as tempura, sushi, and traditional Japanese sweets.

Here's an example:/n/nHTML:/n```html/n/n/n/n /n /n Change Color on Mouse Over/n /n/n/n Hover over me!/n/n/n```/n/nCSS (styles.css):/n```css/n.hover-color {/n color: black;/n transition: color 0.3s;/n}/n/n.hover-color:hover {/n color: red;/n}/n```/n/nIn this example, the `` element has a class called "hover-color". Prompt: You are given an oracle function ```predict_value(stock)```, which returns an estimated confidence interval of p=0.01 around a given stock's value one minute into the future. Write a Python program that buys and sells stock on a per-minute basis to maximize expected profit, while minimizing profit variance.
Response: To maximize expected profit while minimizing profit variance, we can use a simple strategy that buys a stock when the lower bound of the confidence interval is above the current price and sells when the upper bound is below the current price. This way, we are only trading when we have a high confidence that the stock price will move in our favor./n/nHere's a Python program that implements this strategy:/n/n```python/nimport time/nfrom typing import Tuple/n/ndef predict_value(stock: str) -> Tuple[float, float]:/n    # This is a placeholder for the oracle function/n    pass/n/ndef get_current_price(stock: str) -> float:/n    # This function should return the current price of the stock/n    pass/n/ndef buy_stock(stock: str, amount: float) -> None:/n    # This function should buy the specified amount of the stock/n    pass/n/ndef sell_stock(stock: str, amount: float) -> None:/n    # This function should sell the specified amount of the stock/n    pass/n/ndef trade_stock(stock: str, initial_amount: float) -> None:/n    current_amount = initial_amount/n    while True:/n        current_price = get_current_price(stock)/n        lower_bound, upper_bound = predict_value(stock)/n/n        if lower_bound > current_price and current_amount > 0:/n            buy_stock(stock, current_amount)/n            current_amount = 0/n        elif upper_bound < current_price and current_amount < initial_amount:/n            sell_stock(stock, initial_amount - current_amount)/n            current_amount = initial_amount/n/n        time.sleep(60)  # Wait for one minute/n/nif __name__ == "__main__":/n    stock = "AAPL"  # Replace this with the stock you want to trade/n    initial_amount = 1000  # Replace this with the initial amount of money you want to invest/n    trade_stock(stock, initial_amount)/n```/n/nPlease note that this program is just a simple example and should not be used for actual trading without proper modifications and testing. Additionally, you'll need to implement the `get_current_price`, `buy_stock`, and `sell_stock` functions to interact with a real trading platform.
Instruct&Context: You are given an oracle function ```predict_value(stock)```, which returns an estimated confidence interval of p=0.01 around a given stock's value one minute into the future.|||Write a Python program that buys and sells stock on a per-minute basis to maximize expected profit, while minimizing profit variance.

Prompt: Write a stand-up skit in the style of George Carlin that ridicules Pacific Gas and Electric.
Response: Ladies and gentlemen, have you ever heard of a company called Pacific Gas and Electric? Yeah, you know, the guys who are responsible for keeping the lights on and the gas flowing in California. Well, let me tell you something, they're about as reliable as a politician's promise./n/nNow, I don't know about you, but when I think of a utility company, I think of something that's supposed to be, well, useful. But with PG&E, it's more like "Pathetic, Greedy, and Egregious." I mean, these guys have managed to turn the simple act of providing electricity into a game of Russian roulette./n/nYou see, PG&E has this nasty habit of starting wildfires. You know, those things that burn down entire towns and force people to evacuate their homes? Yeah, those. And it's not like it's a one-time thing, either. It's like they're trying to set a high score or something. "Hey, Bob, we only burned down 10,000 acres last year. Think we can hit 20,000 this year?"/n/nAnd the best part is, they don't even try to hide it. They just come out and say, "Yeah, our equipment probably started that fire. Oops." I mean, can you imagine if any other company operated like that? "Hey, sorry about that E. coli outbreak, folks. Our bad. Enjoy your burgers!"/n/nBut don't worry, PG&E has a solution to prevent wildfires: turning off the power. That's right, folks. The company that's supposed to provide electricity has decided that the best way to do that is by not providing electricity. It's like a doctor saying, "Well, the best way to prevent a heart attack is to stop your heart."/n/nAnd when they do shut off the power, it's not like they give you a whole lot of notice. It's like they're trying to surprise you. "Hey, guess what? No electricity for you today! Hope you didn't have anything important to do, like, I don't know, live your life!"/n/nNow, I know what you're thinking. "George, surely there must be some kind of oversight or regulation to keep these guys in check, right?" Well, let me tell you something, folks. The only thing that's being regulated here is the flow of money into PG&E's pockets./n/nYou see, PG&E has this magical ability to avoid any real consequences for their actions. They've filed for bankruptcy, they've been fined, but somehow, they just keep on trucking. It's like they've got a "Get Out of Jail Free" card that never expires./n/nAnd the cherry on top of this flaming disaster sundae? They keep raising their rates! That's right, folks. Not only do they burn down your house and shut off your power, but they also make you pay more for the privilege. It's like getting mugged, and then having the mugger ask you for a tip./n/nSo, the next time you're sitting in the dark, wondering if your house is going to be the next one to go up in flames, just remember: at least you're not a PG&E executive. Because those guys must have a hell of a time sleeping at night. Or maybe they just use all that extra money to buy really, really good earplugs.
Instruct&Context: Write a stand-up skit in the style of George Carlin that ridicules Pacific Gas and Electric.

Prompt: Hi, I have a web app that does google authentication to let users in. How can I replace it with a captcha?
Response:
To replace Google authentication with a CAPTCHA in your web app, you can follow these steps:/n/n1. Choose a CAPTCHA service: There are several CAPTCHA services available, such as Google reCAPTCHA, hCaptcha, and others. For this example, we'll use Google reCAPTCHA./n/n2. Sign up for an API key: Go to the reCAPTCHA website (https://www.google.com/recaptcha) and sign up for an API key. You'll need to provide your domain name and choose the type of CAPTCHA you want to use (reCAPTCHA v2 or reCAPTCHA v3)./n/n3. Add the reCAPTCHA script to your HTML: In the `` section of your HTML file, add the following script:/n/n```html/n/n```/n/n4. Add the reCAPTCHA widget to your form: In your HTML form, add the following code where you want the reCAPTCHA widget to appear:/n/n```html/n
/n```/n/nReplace `your-recaptcha-site-key` with the site key you obtained in step 2./n/n5. Verify the user's response on the server-side: When the form is submitted, you'll need to verify the user's response on the server-side. This can be done using a server-side language like PHP, Node.js, or Python. Here's an example using PHP:/n/n```php/nsuccess) {/n // The CAPTCHA was solved correctly, continue processing the form/n} else {/n // The CAPTCHA was not solved correctly, show an error message/n}/n?>/n```/n/nReplace `your-recaptcha-secret-key` with the secret key you obtained in step 2./n/n6. Remove the Google authentication code: Finally, remove the code related to Google authentication from your web app, as it's no longer needed./n/nThat's it! You've replaced Google authentication with a CAPTCHA in your web app. Users will now need to solve the CAPTCHA to access your app instead of logging in with their Google account.
Instruct&Context: Hi, I have a web app that does google authentication to let users in. How can I replace it with a captcha?

Prompt: Can you explain dependency injection in C# like a gangster?
Response: Yo dawg, listen up! Imma break it down for ya, Dependency Injection (DI) in C# is all about keepin' your code tight and homies workin' together without gettin' all up in each other's business, ya feel me?/n/nSo, imagine you got your crew, right? Each member got their own skills, but they ain't gotta know every lil' detail about the others. They just need to know who to call when they need somethin' done. That's what DI is all about, homie./n/nYou got your classes and interfaces, and they be like your crew members. Instead of havin' them create their own dependencies, you inject them dependencies from the outside, like a boss. This way, they ain't gotta worry about creatin' or findin' the right objects to work with, they just focus on their own job./n/nNow, you might be thinkin', "Why should I care, dawg?" Well, DI helps you keep your code clean, maintainable, and easy to test. Prompt: Can you give a summary of "The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis" by Jonathan Frankle and Michael Carbin?
Response: The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis is a research paper by Jonathan Frankle and Michael Carbin, which proposes a new perspective on the effectiveness of neural networks. The hypothesis suggests that large neural networks contain smaller subnetworks, referred to as "winning tickets," that are capable of learning effectively when trained in isolation. These smaller subnetworks can achieve similar accuracy as the original network but with fewer parameters and faster training times./n/nThe authors conducted experiments on various deep learning models and found that pruning (removing) a significant portion of the network's weights did not negatively impact the performance of the remaining subnetwork. In fact, these pruned networks often achieved better performance than the original, unpruned networks. This finding challenges the conventional wisdom that larger networks are necessary for better performance and suggests that smaller, more efficient networks can be found within larger ones./n/nThe Lottery Ticket Hypothesis has significant implications for the field of deep learning, as it suggests that more efficient training methods and network architectures can be developed by focusing on these "winning tickets." This could lead to faster training times, reduced computational resources, and improved performance in various applications of neural networks.
Instruct&Context: Can you give a summary of "The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis" by Jonathan Frankle and Michael Carbin?

Prompt: How would one solve length generalization with position embeddings?
Response: Length generalization with position embeddings can be addressed by using relative position embeddings instead of absolute position embeddings. Relative position embeddings consider the relative distance between two tokens rather than their absolute positions in the sequence. This allows the model to generalize better to sequences of varying lengths./n/nHere's a step-by-step approach to solving length generalization with position embeddings:/n/n1. Replace absolute position embeddings with relative position embeddings: Instead of using a fixed position embedding for each token based on its absolute position in the sequence, use embeddings that represent the relative distance between pairs of tokens. This can be done by computing the difference between the positions of two tokens and using that difference to look up the corresponding relative position embedding./n/n2. Modify the self-attention mechanism: In the self-attention mechanism, replace the absolute position embeddings with the relative position embeddings. This can be done by adding the relative position embeddings to the attention scores before applying the softmax function. This allows the model to consider the relative distances between tokens when computing attention weights./n/n3. Train the model: Train the model with the modified self-attention mechanism using relative position embeddings. The model should now be able to generalize better to sequences of varying lengths, as it considers the relative distances between tokens rather than their absolute positions./n/n4. Test the model: Evaluate the model on sequences of different lengths to verify that it can generalize well to varying lengths./n/nSome popular models that use relative position embeddings include Transformer-XL and T5. These models have shown improved performance on various natural language processing tasks, especially when dealing with longer sequences.
Instruct&Context: How would one solve length generalization with position embeddings?

Prompt: Why did Apollo 13 fail?
Response: Apollo 13 failed due to an explosion in one of the oxygen tanks in the service module. The explosion occurred on April 13, 1970, when the spacecraft was en route to the Moon. The cause of the explosion was an electrical short circuit in the tank, which was triggered by a combination of manufacturing defects, design issues, and procedural oversights. The explosion damaged the service module, causing a loss of oxygen and power, and forced the mission to be aborted. The crew had to use the lunar module as a "lifeboat" to survive and return safely to Earth. Despite the failure to land on the Moon, the Apollo 13 mission is considered a successful demonstration of the ability of NASA and the astronauts to handle a life-threatening crisis in space.
Instruct&Context: Why did Apollo 13 fail?

Prompt: What can I do for 6 days in the South of France
Response: 1. Explore the French Riviera: Visit the glamorous cities of Nice, Cannes, and Monaco. Stroll along the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, explore the old town (Vieux Nice), and relax on the beautiful beaches. In Cannes, walk along La Croisette and visit the Palais des Festivals, where the Cannes Film Festival takes place. In Monaco, visit the famous Monte Carlo Casino and the Prince's Palace./n/n2. Visit charming coastal towns: Discover the picturesque towns of Antibes, Villefranche-sur-Mer, and Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat. Wander through the narrow streets, visit local markets, and enjoy the stunning views of the Mediterranean Sea./n/n3. Explore the hilltop villages of Provence: Visit the beautiful villages of Gordes, Roussillon, and Ménerbes, which are perched on hilltops and surrounded by stunning landscapes. Enjoy the local cuisine, visit art galleries, and take in the breathtaking views./n/n4. Visit the historic city of Avignon: Explore the UNESCO World Heritage site of the Palais des Papes, the largest Gothic palace in Europe, and the famous Pont d'Avignon. Wander through the charming streets and visit the local markets./n/n5. Discover the Roman ruins in Arles and Nîmes: Visit the ancient Roman amphitheaters, temples, and other ruins in these historic cities. In Arles, don't miss the Roman Arena and the Alyscamps necropolis. In Nîmes, visit the well-preserved Roman temple Maison Carrée and the impressive Pont du Gard aqueduct./n/n6. Experience the natural beauty of the Camargue: This unique wetland area is home to wild horses, pink flamingos, and a variety of bird species. Take a guided tour, go horseback riding, or rent a bike to explore the beautiful landscapes./n/n7. Enjoy the local cuisine and wine: The South of France is known for its delicious food and wine. Visit local markets, try the famous bouillabaisse (fish stew), and sample the region's famous rosé wines./n/n8. Relax on the beaches: The South of France is home to some beautiful beaches, such as Plage de Pampelonne in Saint-Tropez, Paloma Beach in Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, and Plage de la Garoupe in Antibes. Spend a day soaking up the sun and swimming in the crystal-clear waters./n/n9. Visit the lavender fields: If you're visiting in the summer, don't miss the stunning lavender fields in Provence. The best time to see them in full bloom is from late June to early August./n/n10. Take a boat trip to the Calanques: These stunning limestone cliffs and hidden coves can be found along the coast between Marseille and Cassis. Take a boat tour or hike along the coastal trails to discover these beautiful natural wonders.
Instruct&Context: What can I do for 6 days in the South of France

Prompt: how to relieve stress from work
Response: 1. Take breaks: Regular breaks throughout the day can help you recharge and refocus. Step away from your desk, take a short walk, or do some light stretching to clear your mind./n/n2. Prioritize tasks: Make a to-do list and prioritize tasks based on importance and deadlines. This can help you feel more in control and reduce stress./n/n3. Set boundaries: Establish a clear separation between work and personal life. Avoid checking work emails or taking work calls during your personal time./n/n4. Practice time management: Break tasks into smaller, manageable steps and set realistic deadlines. This can help you avoid feeling overwhelmed./n/n5. Exercise: Physical activity can help reduce stress and improve your mood. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate exercise most days of the week./n/n6. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, and progressive muscle relaxation can help calm your mind and reduce stress./n/n7. Get enough sleep: Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep each night to help your body and mind recover from the day's stress./n/n8. Maintain a healthy diet: Eating a balanced diet can help provide the energy and nutrients needed to cope with stress./n/n9. Connect with others: Share your feelings with friends, family, or colleagues who can offer support and encouragement./n/n10. Seek professional help: If stress is affecting your ability to function at work or in your personal life, consider talking to a mental health professional for guidance and support.
Instruct&Context: how to relieve stress from work

Prompt: Why do my fiddle fig leaves look yellow?
Response: There are several reasons why your fiddle fig leaves might look yellow:/n/n1. Overwatering: Fiddle figs don't like to sit in water, and overwatering can cause the leaves to turn yellow. Make sure you're allowing the soil to dry out between waterings./n/n2. Underwatering: If the plant isn't getting enough water, the leaves can also turn yellow. Make sure you're watering your fiddle fig consistently and providing enough moisture./n/n3. Poor drainage: If the pot doesn't have proper drainage, the roots can become waterlogged, leading to yellow leaves. Ensure your pot has drainage holes and consider adding a layer of pebbles at the bottom to improve drainage./n/n4. Nutrient deficiency: A lack of essential nutrients, such as nitrogen, can cause yellowing leaves. Fertilize your fiddle fig with a balanced, slow-release fertilizer during the growing season./n/n5. Root rot: If the roots are rotting due to overwatering or poor drainage, the leaves may turn yellow. You may need to repot the plant in fresh soil and trim away any damaged roots./n/n6. Pests or diseases: Pests like spider mites or diseases like fungal infections can cause yellowing leaves. Inspect your plant for signs of pests or disease and treat accordingly./n/n7. Natural aging: Older leaves may turn yellow and fall off as part of the plant's natural growth process. This is normal and not a cause for concern./n/nTo determine the cause of yellow leaves on your fiddle fig, examine the plant's overall health, watering habits, and growing conditions. Adjust your care routine as needed to address any issues and promote healthy growth.
Instruct&Context: Why do my fiddle fig leaves look yellow?
